awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of an innovative software architecture for co-robots and smart devices to augment human capacity with regard to mundane tasking in the service sector
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be to create a user-friendly, universal control
system for robots and sensors that for the first time would make it possible for nontechnical service
industry professionals to task and control co-robots deployed in their facility. This simplification of
software for an end-user will make systems of robots as easy to control as a single robot. Data collected
over the lifecycle of the robots and sensors (which is currently not done) may aid in identification of new
technologies to revolutionize system capabilities in the field of robotics. Although this concept could be
applied to a wide array of service sector industries, SRT proposes to efficiently integrate and
cooperatively control a fleet of robots and sensors to support custodial service industry tasks, because?
though essential?custodial services add no commercial value to an organization. Thus the sector is
clamoring for ways to reduce personnel turnover and other costs. In the U.S., custodial services are a $40
billion industry; a mere 5% increase in efficiency would result in $2 billion in savings annually. This
sector is rife with robots from disparate manufacturers, yet facility managers need an easy-to-use method
to ?employ? multiple, specialized robots.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a common software
architecture that will serve as a universal receptor for service robotics systems. The predominant technical
hurdle is effectively combining the software protocols and coordinating control of the robots. There
currently is no common standard for robotics software systems. The actual robot (the hardware) is
typically the primary focus for product developers, while the software is built from a variety of
proprietary, heritage and open sources, and is as unique as the company developing it. Little or no
consideration is given to how robots from different manufacturers could interact in the real world. By
standardizing the data protocols for robots and smart devices, and making that openly available, SRT
intends to drive future open API development for hardware. Standardized APIs will still protect the
proprietary components, but will quickly allow for data sharing across multiple devices?facilitating
research in robotics, machine learning, and big data?by allowing end-users to quickly integrate multiple
components into the same system, and develop their own algorithms to utilize the shared data streams.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Service Robotics & Technologies (SRT) developed a communication standard that would allows for a variety of smart devices (commercial off-the-shelf service robots and IoT devices) to share data through a common framework, providing the means for a facility manager to monitor and control these devices from a single dashboard. Currently, most companies develop their hardware and software to interface together directly, but with limited accessibility to or from outside sources, meaning the devices are never working within one "ecosystem." The result of our innovative R&D was to bring multiple smart devices together into a single map-based interface. This not only allows for easier monitoring and control of these devices, but also allows for advanced analytics and opens the doors to autonomous decision-making to be performed across the deployed fleet of devices.

There were four major outcomes from this project. (1) SRT was able to create this standard communications protocol and integrate data from a 11 different devices from 6 different companies (exceeding our proposed 6 devices from 3 companies). (2) We then built a demonstration display of this data on an integrated dashboard. (3) SRT has successfully deployed the software and a select fleet of devices into a school district for demonstration and evaluation purposes. (4) The data from this (and further demo deployments in the coming months) will allow for significant data collection from the deployed devices, allowing for SRT to prepare for the integration of additional devices (currently funded by Virginia’s Center for Innovative Technology on an SBIR matching funds grant) and the understanding of the end-users’ needs so as to provide additional actionable information through our dashboard.

The intellectual merit of this project was in demonstrating that data from multiple robotic systems can be streamlined into a common data structure (in addition to IoT devices), allowing for the integration of data into a shared database, paving the way for integrated mapping and control for robotics. The knowledge that SRT gained during Phase I is also being shared on the international stage. SRT is currently working with ISO TC299 committee on the development of standards for service robotics modularity in hardware and software. By systematizing the data protocols for robots and smart devices, SRT intends to drive future API development for hardware devices towards a common standard. Standardized APIs will still protect the proprietary components but will quickly allow for data sharing across multiple devices—facilitating research in robotics, machine learning, and big data—by allowing end-users to quickly integrate multiple components into the same system and develop their own algorithms to utilize the shared data streams.

The broader impacts of this user-friendly, universal control system for robots and sensors, has made it possible for nontechnical service industry professionals to task and control co-robots and smart devices deployed in their facility. The ever-growing IoT market means there is no shortage of hardware developers who have creative solutions to the problems that commercial facilities face. Amongst all of this great hardware though, software has often been an afterthought! SRT’s patent-pending software framework (the M1) provides this standardization which enables compatibility across manufacturers and between devices.SRT’s work is innovative and will propel the smart facilities market forward: SRT has created an integrated framework so that multiple robots from different manufacturers can be collaboratively controlled, and by standardizing the data protocols, data from one device can autonomously influence the decision making of another device in the infrastructure.

SRT’s M1 provides clients with a completely integrated service robotics solution. This is a philosophical change in the mindset of how the custodial industry currently implements robotics and smart devices, shifting from using each device as a tool (one person monitors one independent device) to a model where a custodial manager uses a fleet of systems to accomplish mundane and repetitive tasks (one person remotely tasks multiple autonomous systems). The industry both needs and desires this change. Every custodial manager that SRT has met with, from Fortune 200 to small companies, has expressed a desire to use technology more effectively to reduce costs and improve oversight in their facilities.

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2018
Modified by: Gregory P Scott
